entry.title: Re: What exactly is SAP BW PCE… and what it is not !
entry.content:
Hello Mel,

Your existing BW 7.5 PCE deployment in US20 can stay where it is, regardless where the public cloud components of BDC are deployed. That's because there's no co-location requirement for the private and public component services.

Your SAP sales team can help you restructure your existing contract to fit the BW landscape under the BDC commercial umbrella and with that, you'd have access to the Data Product Generator. In addition,  you can plan for a reduction of the BW landscape (aka scale-down) , free up the BW-dedicated capacity units, and then use them for the public cloud component services.

I hope this helps,
Karsten

entry.title: Re: Cracking the “!” Mystery in SAP on Sybase ASE: Why isql Rejects Your Password
entry.content:
You're still not out of the woods.

In unix/linux shells (eg, bash, ksh) , if the password contains a dollar sign ($) and is either a) not wrapped in quotes or b) is wrapped in double quotes then the $ is treated by the shell as an indicator of a (shell) variable reference.

Consider:

$ echo 123$x456
123

$ echo "123$x456"
123

$ echo '123$x456'
123$x456

$ echo 123$456
12356

$ echo "123$456"
12356

$ echo '123$456'
123$456

In the 1st and 2nd cases (no quotes, double quotes) the shell thinks $x456 is a variable reference and  since (in this case) there is no variable named x456 the shell replaces $x456 with an empty string (ie, nothing) so the echo only sees 123.

In the 3rd case (single quotes) the shell makes no attempt to interpret the contents (within the single quotes) so the $ is treated as a literal character and the echo sees the entire string.

In the 4th and 5th cases (no quotes, double quotes) the $4 is treated by the shell as a reference to the 4th input parameter to the script; assuming there is no 4th input parameter the shell replaces $4 with an empty string (ie, nothing) so the echo sees 12356.

In the 6th case (single quotes) the shell makes no attempt to interpret the contents (within the single quotes) so the $ is treated as a literal character and the echo sees the entire string 123$456.

------------------

Net result:

  • several of the characters listed as Valid special character have special meaning to unix/linux shells; single quotes should disable the (unix/linux) shell's attempts to interpret said characters
  • only one set of (single) quotes is necessary so ...
  • in the isql/password example it should be sufficient to use -P 'a!terpwd123'
  • NOTE: for an embedded single quote (also a Valid special character !!) switching to double quotes would be one solution, eg, "sample'string", 'sample'"'"'string' - in the 2nd case the middle '"'"' is a single quote (match leading single quote) plus "  '  " (wrap single quote in double quote) plus single quote (match trailing single quote)

entry.title: Unable Time Recording Changes on SAP Public Cloud- Professional Services
entry.content:
Hi SAP Community,

We are currently working on a SAP Public Cloud – Professional Services greenfield implementation. The customer does not have payroll integration and intends to use SAP data to perform payroll in another system.

The configuration we would like to implement is to restrict the ability to adjust timesheets for previous payroll weeks. Specifically, we want to prevent modifications in the “Manage My Timesheets” app for the two weeks prior to the current working week.

In exploring the configuration option “Maintain Data Entry Profile (S/4HANA: SCIUSS: 102509)”, we have found the “No changes after approval” setting but have not identified additional scope items to handle this specific requirement.

Do you have any insights on the feasibility of this? Our intent is not to block entire weeks, but only the past two weeks relative to the current working period.

Thank you in advance for your guidance.
Melis

entry.title: Navigating SAP Security and Cloud Compliance Topics
entry.content:
Navigating SAP Security and Cloud Compliance Topics

SAP offers customers several options to find resources and information on security and cloud compliance topics within our solution suite. This blog will walk you through some of the options, including:

  • the SAP Trust Center,
  • SAP for Me,
  • the My Trust Center, and also
  • how to navigate within the SAP Community

Our aim is to help our customers find the information they need with ease.

SAP Trust Center (Public Facing)

The SAP Trust Center helps customers understand the framework behind Security, Privacy, and Compliance with SAP. From here customers can also learn how to report security issues or discover SAP’s security products and services, access agreements, have visibility into cloud availability, and more.

On the compliance side, the SAP Trust Center highlights SAP’s routine audits and certification documentation including: ISO/IEC, SOC, bridge letters, and industry-specific standards like TISAX (Trusted Information Security Assessment Exchange). For customers and stakeholders who want to know how SAP demonstrates security, trust, and transparency practices, we invite you to visit the SAP Trust Center.

SAP for Me - (SAP valid S-user ID)

SAP for Me is designed to provide SAP customers on-demand access to cloud compliance documents such as certifications, attestations, and SOC reports. Eligible users with a customer account can employ filters, like Offering Type, Compliance Entity, Assessment Period or Region/Country to identify required resources. As part of the Portfolio and Products section of SAP for Me, this tool serves as the go-to destination for downloading compliance documents quickly and securely for authorized users.

Beyond compliance, SAP for Me also acts as a digital companion, consolidating alerts, metrics, and delivering insights about your SAP product portfolio in one central place. SAP for Me is a time saver in today’s fast paced environment.

My Trust Center (SAP valid S-user ID)

Within the SAP Trust Center, the My Trust Center amplifies the experience for SAP customers and partners by offering authenticated access to customer-facing resources and enablement materials. The My Trust Center offers customers the ability to subscribe to specific resources, so subscribers are notified by e-mail whenever relevant content is updated. This feature saves you from having to check back for new versions.

Customers can access information about SAP’s subprocessors and data fact sheets, as well as explore regulatory requirements across different regions. It also includes policies, frameworks, and support schedules that help you align your governance frameworks with SAP’s standards. These resources are intended to support customers with regulatory obligations within their organization.

SAP Community (Public Facing)

Of course, compliance is not just about official documents, it is also about the shared knowledge and experiences that help customers put best practices into action. The SAP Community has 1.4 million members and it is one of the best places for collaboration across products, industries, and regions. The SAP Community knowledge base serves as a growing library of documents and resources that offer insights, related links, and contributions from SAP experts and customers.

Alongside the SAP Community knowledge base, users can access the Security and Compliance interest group to catch up with blogs and discussion posts that offer real-world perspectives on cyber resilience, AI, regulatory changes, and more. The SAP Community gives users the ability to search for answers, leave comments or ask experts questions, and even contribute thoughts or best practices. Overall, the SAP Community is a great place to not only find information but also learn from others who have experienced similar challenges and successes as your own.

SAP User Groups (Public Facing)

Another valuable channel for customers and users to expand their knowledge and exchange experiences is through SAP User Groups. These independent not-for-profit groups offer opportunities for networking, collaboration, and learning among peers. On a global scale, user groups host webcasts, local events, and special interest sessions that encourage dialogue and hands-on learning. Whether engaging at a regional level or connecting across international networks, SAP User Groups allow customers direct access to practical experiences and shared expertise that complement SAP’s own platforms and resources.

Conclusion

Whether a customer is searching for official certifications, a transparent view of SAP’s best practices, tailored compliance reports, or community driven knowledge, SAP provides accessible tools to support every step of your engagement journey.

Bookmark the pages below and share them with your team to stay informed.  

Link Repository

Platform

Link

SAP for Me

https://me.sap.com/

Access and Authorizations

https://support.sap.com/content/s4m/help/access/user-admin-concept.html

SAP Trust Center

https://www.sap.com/about/trust-center.html

My Trust Center

https://support.sap.com/en/my-support/trust-center.html

SAP Community

https://community.sap.com/

SAP Community Security and Compliance Interest Group

https://community.sap.com/t5/security-and-compliance/gh-p/security-compliance

SAP User Groups

https://www.sap.com/about/user-groups.html

entry.title: RAP Event: consume SAP standard event and trigger custom RAP event
entry.content:
1. Introduction

Event-driven architecture (EDA) is an integrated model that detects critical business "events" and responds to them in real time. As modern businesses seek real-time operations and flexible, responsive systems, EDA has become an essential technology.
Many standard RAP events are provided for the implementation of the event-driven architecture in SAP S/4HANA, but the standard event payload may not meet business requirements and require customization. In particular, there is a use case where SAP standard events are extended with Derived Events for the purpose of filtering by event data and payload completion of standard events.
Derived Event is available in S/4HANA Cloud, private edition & S/4HANA 2023 / S/4HANA Cloud, public edition Introduced in the 2308 release, this feature allows you to define new events with custom payloads based on existing SAP standard events. This allows you to reuse standard event implementations while creating events with additional fields and filtering criteria that you need for your business.
SAP Community Blog: Derived Events- How to Trigger Custom Event from an SAP Standard Event
On the other hand, a Derived Event requires that the SAP Standard object to be extended meets the following conditions:

  • The business object containing the referring event must be extensible.
  • The referenced event must be published on the C0 and C1 released RAP BO interfaces
  • The CDS view entity used as the data source for the Derived Event payload must have been released in C1

Therefore, some objects do not support extensibility with Derived Events in SAP Standard RAP BO. In this case, there may be cases where the requirements that should be solved by Derived Events cannot be realized.
So, in this blog, we will introduce a workaround approach that enables payload expansion with custom RAP BO for SAP standard events that cannot be extended with Derived Events.

 

2. Workaround Solutions

If Derived Events are not available, a workaround approach that combines Local Event Consumption with custom RAP events can be an effective approach. This approach involves consuming SAP standard events locally (custom ABAP classes) and using them as triggers to raise custom RAP events. By setting the payload of a custom event to meet your business requirements, you can use event filters.

 

3. Implementation Sample

In this blog, we will use a non-extensible r_purchaseordertp as the target object to extend the event payload for data changes in a PO document. SAP standard events have a payload of only the purchase order document number, whereas custom events have a purchase order document number and purchase order type as the payload. For more information on Event Binding and channel configuration with Event Mesh, please visit the SAP Community Blog: https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-sap/how-to-create-rap-business-events-in-sap-s-4hana-on-premise-2022/ba-p/13553312 . Please note that the RAP BO in the implementation sample in this blog does not implement CRUD or save processing other than events.

 

(1) Local Consumer (Custom ABAP Class for Local Event Consumption)

Global class: zcl_event_consump

In the Global class, the definition FOR EVENTS OF r_purchaseordertp sets the standard events to be consumed.

CLASS zcl_event_consump DEFINITION
  PUBLIC
  ABSTRACT
  FINAL
  FOR EVENTS OF r_purchaseordertp.

  PUBLIC SECTION.
  PROTECTED SECTION.
  PRIVATE SECTION.
ENDCLASS.



CLASS zcl_event_consump IMPLEMENTATION.
ENDCLASS.

 

Local class: zcl_event_consump

The Local class performs additional data retrieval based on the data from the standard event payload consumed to trigger a custom RAP event.
It is important to note that triggering events is only possible in the RAP framework with a Save Sequence, so you must explicitly change it to Save Sequence by cl_abap_tx=>save( ).

*"* use this source file for the definition and implementation of
*"* local helper classes, interface definitions and type
*"* declarations
CLASS lcl_event_consump DEFINITION INHERITING FROM cl_abap_behavior_event_handler.
  PRIVATE SECTION.
    METHODS:
      consume_changed FOR ENTITY EVENT changed_instances FOR purchaseorder~changed.
ENDCLASS.

CLASS lcl_event_consump IMPLEMENTATION.

  METHOD consume_changed.
    cl_abap_tx=>save(  ).

    DATA lv_potype TYPE mm_purchaseordertype.

    CHECK changed_instances IS NOT INITIAL.

    LOOP AT changed_instances INTO DATA(changed_instance).

      SELECT SINGLE purchaseordertype
      FROM c_purchaseordertp
      INTO _potype
      WHERE purchaseorder = @changed_instance-purchaseorder.

      DATA(et_events) = VALUE zbp_i_purchseorder_test=>tt_events(
        (
        purchaseorder = changed_instance-purchaseorder
        purchaseordertype = lv_potype
        )
      ).

      zbp_i_purchseorder_event=>raise_po_changed_event( it_events = et_events ).

    ENDLOOP.

  ENDMETHOD.

ENDCLASS.

 

(2) Custom RAP BO (Custom Event)

CDS View: ZI_purchseorder_event

In the CDS View, I define only the purchase order.

@AbapCatalog.viewEnhancementCategory: [#NONE]
@AccessControl.authorizationCheck: #NOT_REQUIRED
@EndUserText.label: 'Consume purchase order event'
@Metadata.ignorePropagatedAnnotations: true
@ObjectModel.usageType:{
  serviceQuality: #X,
  sizeCategory: #S,
  dataClass: #MIXED
}
define root view entity ZI_purchseorder_event as select from I_PurchaseOrder
{
  key PurchaseOrder
}
 
Behavior Definition: ZI_purchseorder_event

Custom RAP BO for event triggers does not define the create/update/delete function.

managed with unmanaged save implementation in class zbp_i_purchseorder_event unique;
strict ( 2 );

define behavior for ZI_purchseorder_event //alias <alias_name>
//persistent table ekko
lock master
authorization master ( instance )
//etag master <field_name>
{
  //  create;
  //  update;
  //  delete;
  event purchaseorder_changed parameter ZAB_PO_changed_event;

  field ( readonly ) PurchaseOrder;
}
Behavior Implementation (Global class) : zbp_i_purchseorder_event

In the Global class, I define a method for triggering events.

CLASS zbp_i_purchseorder_event DEFINITION PUBLIC ABSTRACT FINAL FOR BEHAVIOR OF zi_purchseorder_event.

  TYPES tt_events TYPE TABLE FOR EVENT zi_purchseorder_event~purchaseorder_changed.

  PUBLIC SECTION.
        CLASS-METHODS raise_po_changed_event
            IMPORTING it_events TYPE tt_events.

ENDCLASS.

CLASS zbp_i_purchseorder_event IMPLEMENTATION.
METHOD raise_po_changed_event.
  lcl_event_handler=>on_po_changed_event( it_events ).
endmethod.
ENDCLASS.
 
Behavior Implementation (Local class) : lhc_zi_purchseorder_event

The Local class does not implement save processing, etc., but only implements methods for triggering events.

CLASS lhc_zi_purchseorder_event DEFINITION INHERITING FROM cl_abap_behavior_handler.
  PRIVATE SECTION.

    METHODS get_instance_authorizations FOR INSTANCE AUTHORIZATION
      IMPORTING keys REQUEST requested_authorizations FOR zi_purchseorder_event RESULT result.

ENDCLASS.

CLASS lhc_zi_purchseorder_event IMPLEMENTATION.

  METHOD get_instance_authorizations.
  ENDMETHOD.

ENDCLASS.

CLASS lsc_zi_purchseorder_event DEFINITION INHERITING FROM cl_abap_behavior_saver.
  PROTECTED SECTION.

    METHODS save_modified REDEFINITION.

    METHODS cleanup_finalize REDEFINITION.

ENDCLASS.

CLASS lsc_zi_purchseorder_event IMPLEMENTATION.

  METHOD save_modified.
  ENDMETHOD.

  METHOD cleanup_finalize.
  ENDMETHOD.

ENDCLASS.

CLASS lcl_event_handler DEFINITION FRIENDS zbp_i_purchseorder_event.
  PUBLIC SECTION.
    CLASS-METHODS on_po_changed_event IMPORTING it_events TYPE zbp_i_purchseorder_event=>tt_events.
ENDCLASS.

CLASS lcl_event_handler IMPLEMENTATION.
   METHOD on_po_changed_event.

    RAISE ENTITY EVENT ZI_purchseorder_event~purchaseorder_changed FROM it_events.

   ENDMETHOD.
ENDCLASS.
 
Abstract Entity: ZAB_PO_changed_event

Abstract entity adds a purchase order document type. This results in the payload of the custom RAP event being the purchase order document number and the purchase order document type.

@EndUserText.label: 'Abastract entity for po changed event'
define abstract entity ZAB_PO_changed_event
  //  with parameters parameter_name : parameter_type
{
  PurchaseOrderType : mm_purchaseordertype;
}

 

4. Implementation Results

Modify and save an existing purchase order document from the Manage Purchase Orders (F0842A) app.

 

You can receive custom events triggered from S/4HANA in SAP Event Mesh.

 

5. Summary

When it is not possible to scale with Derived Events in implementing an event-driven architecture, a workaround approach that combines Local Event Consumption with custom RAP events is an effective approach.
This approach enables custom payloads and filtering capabilities based on business requirements, providing event consumers with the data they need to optimize cross-system integration.

 

References

entry.title: Navigating SAP Security and Cloud Compliance Topics
entry.content:
Navigating SAP Security and Cloud Compliance Topics

SAP offers customers several options to find resources and information on security and cloud compliance topics within our solution suite. This blog will walk you through some of the options, including:

  • the SAP Trust Center,
  • SAP for Me,
  • the My Trust Center, and also
  • how to navigate within the SAP Community

Our aim is to help our customers find the information they need with ease.

SAP Trust Center (Public Facing)

The SAP Trust Center helps customers understand the framework behind Security, Privacy, and Compliance with SAP. From here customers can also learn how to report security issues or discover SAP’s security products and services, access agreements, have visibility into cloud availability, and more.

On the compliance side, the SAP Trust Center highlights SAP’s routine audits and certification documentation including: ISO/IEC, SOC, bridge letters, and industry-specific standards like TISAX (Trusted Information Security Assessment Exchange). For customers and stakeholders who want to know how SAP demonstrates security, trust, and transparency practices, we invite you to visit the SAP Trust Center.

SAP for Me - (SAP valid S-user ID)

SAP for Me is designed to provide SAP customers on-demand access to cloud compliance documents such as certifications, attestations, and SOC reports. Eligible users with a customer account can employ filters, like Offering Type, Compliance Entity, Assessment Period or Region/Country to identify required resources. As part of the Portfolio and Products section of SAP for Me, this tool serves as the go-to destination for downloading compliance documents quickly and securely for authorized users.

Beyond compliance, SAP for Me also acts as a digital companion, consolidating alerts, metrics, and delivering insights about your SAP product portfolio in one central place. SAP for Me is a time saver in today’s fast paced environment.

My Trust Center (SAP valid S-user ID)

Within the SAP Trust Center, the My Trust Center amplifies the experience for SAP customers and partners by offering authenticated access to customer-facing resources and enablement materials. The My Trust Center offers customers the ability to subscribe to specific resources, so subscribers are notified by e-mail whenever relevant content is updated. This feature saves you from having to check back for new versions.

Customers can access information about SAP’s subprocessors and data fact sheets, as well as explore regulatory requirements across different regions. It also includes policies, frameworks, and support schedules that help you align your governance frameworks with SAP’s standards. These resources are intended to support customers with regulatory obligations within their organization.

SAP Community (Public Facing)

Of course, compliance is not just about official documents, it is also about the shared knowledge and experiences that help customers put best practices into action. The SAP Community has 1.4 million members and it is one of the best places for collaboration across products, industries, and regions. The SAP Community knowledge base serves as a growing library of documents and resources that offer insights, related links, and contributions from SAP experts and customers.

Alongside the SAP Community knowledge base, users can access the Security and Compliance interest group to catch up with blogs and discussion posts that offer real-world perspectives on cyber resilience, AI, regulatory changes, and more. The SAP Community gives users the ability to search for answers, leave comments or ask experts questions, and even contribute thoughts or best practices. Overall, the SAP Community is a great place to not only find information but also learn from others who have experienced similar challenges and successes as your own.

SAP User Groups (Public Facing)

Another valuable channel for customers and users to expand their knowledge and exchange experiences is through SAP User Groups. These independent not-for-profit groups offer opportunities for networking, collaboration, and learning among peers. On a global scale, user groups host webcasts, local events, and special interest sessions that encourage dialogue and hands-on learning. Whether engaging at a regional level or connecting across international networks, SAP User Groups allow customers direct access to practical experiences and shared expertise that complement SAP’s own platforms and resources.

 

Conclusion

Whether a customer is searching for official certifications, a transparent view of SAP’s best practices, tailored compliance reports, or community driven knowledge, SAP provides accessible tools to support every step of your engagement journey.

Bookmark the pages below and share them with your team to stay informed.  

Link Repository

Platform

Link

SAP for Me

https://me.sap.com/

Access and Authorizations

https://support.sap.com/content/s4m/help/access/user-admin-concept.html

SAP Trust Center

https://www.sap.com/about/trust-center.html

My Trust Center

https://support.sap.com/en/my-support/trust-center.html

SAP Community

https://community.sap.com/

SAP Community Security and Compliance Interest Group

https://community.sap.com/t5/security-and-compliance/gh-p/security-compliance

SAP User Groups

https://www.sap.com/about/user-groups.html

entry.title: Re: SAP CPI to Microsoft SharePoint Adapter Integration
entry.content:
Alex,

these instructions seem to be not correct and are incomplete - it doesn't work, many users seem to get the same error as I: Invalid Audience.

- Is the scope really https://graph.microsoft.com/.default, and not https://[tenant].sharepoint.com/.default? 

- Is it correct to leave the field 'Audience' blank in the oauth2 security material? 

- Is the token URL correct as follows?: https://login.microsoftonline.com/xxx-xxx-xxx-xxx-xxx/oauth2/v2.0/token?  Or are you using token endpoint v1?    

By the way, I don't think the headers have to be set in the IFlow. That's implicitly done in the token request, and not required for the POST to the server.

entry.title: Re: Building Sustainable Supply Chains: From Design to Reuse
entry.content:
Key Takeaways: Building Sustainable Supply Chains.
Sustainability is essential: It’s no longer just a compliance requirement but a way to gain a competitive edge.

Circular supply chains are key: Focus on reducing environmental impact at every stage—from design to reuse.

Smart design choices can significantly reduce a product's environmental footprint.

Planning with sustainability: Tools like SAP IBP help integrate sustainability into decision-making, from carbon footprint optimization to compliance.

Procurement as a driver: Sustainable sourcing is crucial for reducing environmental impact, supported by SAP tools like Ariba and Sustainability Data Exchange.

Manufacturing & logistics: Focus on minimizing emissions, waste, and energy use at every step of production and transportation.

Circular practices: Reuse and remanufacturing help reduce waste, cut costs, and create new business opportunities.

entry.title: Re: How to run "local" tRFC via bgRFC? (local: with no destination or 'NONE')
entry.content:
I don't know if 'NONE' is to be considered outbound or inbound, because there's no queue implied.

tRFC = "once only in any order (transactional)"

I don't see any difference with the inbound scenario:

" Create the inbound destination (queue) 'ZZZINBQ' in SBGRFCCONF
DATA(lo_destination_rfc) = cl_bgrfc_destination_inbound=>create( 'ZZZINBQ' ).
DATA(lo_trfc_unit) = lo_destination_rfc->create_trfc_unit( ).
CALL FUNCTION 'Z_RFC'
     IN BACKGROUND UNIT lo_trfc_unit
     EXPORTING iv_vbeln = iv_vbeln.

 There is this "bgRFC type t" example in the SAP Library, there's no example with outbound:

DATA: my_destination TYPE REF TO if_bgrfc_destination_inbound,
      my_unit        TYPE REF TO if_trfc_unit_inbound,
      lock_id        TYPE bgrfc_lock_id,
      dest_name      TYPE bgrfc_dest_name_inbound.

dest_name = 'MY_DEST'.
my_destination = cl_bgrfc_destination_inbound=>create( dest_name ).
my_unit = my_destination->create_trfc_unit( ). 
CALL FUNCTION 'rfc_function_1' IN BACKGROUND UNIT my_unit. 
CALL FUNCTION 'rfc_function_2' IN BACKGROUND UNIT my_unit.
lock_id = my_unit->delay( 300 ).
COMMIT WORK.

So, I return your question 😉 :

Why should I use a dummy inbound destination with inbound bgRFC type t?

What means outbound and inbound in bgRFC type t, how to program them, together, separately, ...?

Of course, it's a discussion, I don't understand the specificities of the bgRFC type t concept.

entry.title: Generate PDF form on S/4HANA Cloud, public edition from BTP app
entry.content:
I’m building a BTP CAP application which should retrieve the PDF printout of an Outbound Delivery (FDP_V2_DELIVERY_NOTE_V1 template )out of an S/4HANA Cloud, public edition system.

Since no direct API exists (like for billing documents Overview | Billing Document - Read, Cancel, GetPDF | SAP Business Accelerator Hub), as per my understanding I’m left with three options:

  1. Recreate the same form I have on S/4HANA on BTP with SAP Forms Service by Adobe
  2. Get the PDF directly from CA_OC_OUTPUT_REQUEST_SRV Service
  3. Create a small custom ABAP service to be called from BTP which, given a specific delivery number, could return a PDF

I tried all those routes, but couldn’t succeed for various reasons:

  1. SAP Forms Service by Adobe
    1. it seems I can’t reuse the layout I made since the service only accept only one file, whereas mine is comprised of a master form and a content for
    2. even if I could recreate it from scratch I don't know how I can get data out of the standard Data Provider (FDP_V2_DELIV_NOTE_LO_GLO_GEN_SRV) to pass it to the layout
  2. this does not seem to be a released API, therefore I think I could have a problem with Communication Arrangement technical user
  3. on Premise FM like ‘FP_JOB_OPEN’ etc.. are obviously forbidden, so I tried with proper classes like cl_fp_form_reader like suggested in Note 3355397 - No support for custom form templates in S/4 HANA Cloud Developer Extensibility - SAP for Me, however,  since the form was created using Maintain Form Template App, I tried to create in ADT, but no standard Data Provider can be chosen and I can’t even create my own copy with the proper annotations (as explained in note 3650179 - [2508] Cannot select data provider in ADT Form dialog - SAP for Me) because I can’t open SEGW on a Public Cloud environment.

I’ve hit a dead end. Can someone share a tip?

entry.title: Re: SPECIAL GL TRANSACTION RELATED TO VENDOR IN SAP S/4 H...
entry.content:
Use Separate SP GL Indicators: 

You can have multiple special G/L indicators (type “A” for down payment) in Public Cloud — but you must configure them through SSCUI (Self-Service Configuration UI).

Configuration path:

Manage Your Solution → Finance → Accounts Payable → Business Transactions → Down Payment → Define Alternative Reconciliation Accounts for Special G/L Transactions

Here you can:

  • Create  Special G/L indicators (e.g., A1, A2)

  • Assign different reconciliation accounts for each indicator

WHT Implication: 

In India localization for Public Cloud, TDS is triggered during:

  • Vendor invoice posting, or

  • Advance payment posting (if applicable), depending on tax type and configuration

If you want TDS only for Ad-hoc Advances, you define through Vendor Payment Process

  • Use different special G/L indicators as above

  • Maintain withholding tax codes (in Business Partner → Company Code → Withholding Tax tab)

  • For Mobilization Advances → use WHT code with No tax base (or exempt rate)

  • For Ad-hoc Advances → use proper WHT type & code (e.g., Section 194C)

entry.title: SAP Community Voice: ABAP Innovations, Rules on GenAI for content creation and Devtoberfest recap!
entry.content:
In just the first two weeks of October, we’ve already seen amazing blog posts from community members and SAP employees. Including step-by-step guides to make your ABAP journey smoother, new features in the Clean Core Cloudification Repository Viewer, SAP Joule for Developers hitting a new milestone and exciting new set of Badges!

Have you joined any Devtoberfest sessions yet? Participated in Fun Activities? Collected points along the way? We are also reminding you, that this free and online event is a must for the month!

Ans there’s plenty more initiatives and events happening across the SAP community all over the world. Let’s dive in and see what’s new!

Featured blog posts

New features on Clean Core Cloudification Repository Viewer  

Going through your SAP Clean Core journey? Then this overview about the new Clean Core Cloudification Repository Viewer (CRV), by SAP´s Rudong_Liu, is a must read! With his hands-on experience supporting RISE with SAP Customers, he showed all the new features in this update version, that includes clearer interface with filters for product, release, state, and Clean Core levels. A highlight is the introduction of the “Partner Namespace”, which certified partners are now able to publish released APIs as well. Make sure to check the whole blog post, to have a look at the guide with images and explanations on how to navigate and improve the experience with CRV.

Read the blog post here

ABAP RAP – How to Excel upload through custom action popup

Mass data changes that are uploaded via Excel, sometimes can be challenging because the execution often requires a custom action popup. Involving U15 extensions, third-party solutions or Object Page manipulations. But, on the latest blog post by the community member Ramjee Korada, he walks through the 10 steps on implementing the new ABAP/CAP annotations, that allows developers to prioritize implementing core business logic over developing reusable technical artifacts. This feature is currently functional on the BTP ABAP Environment.

Read the blog post here

News about SAP Joule for Developers and ABAP AI capabilities

Last week big news about accelerating ABAP innovation and transformation were released, and SAP´s Sonja Lienard gave our members a full overview on the updates. Joule for Developers and ABAP AI capabilities are now available in SAP S/4HANA Private Cloud Edition 2025. Additionally, the new Custom Code Migration capabilities accelerate the transformation of classic ERP code to S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition, including Documentation Chat (answers on SAP S/4HANA simplifications), ABAP Program Explain (purpose and logic of legacy code) and Explain for SAP S/4HANA Test Cockpit Issues (diagnosis and resolution using simplification items and cookbooks). Also, a big highlight is that SAP Joule for Developers will remain free of charge!

Read the blog post here

Pallets in SAP CPI Integration Flows

If you are trying to find a step-by-step on how to use Pallet in SAP CPI, the content produced by the community member Ankit Singh prepared, could be what you been looking for. Using the example of a toolbox, this feature allows to drag and drop frequently used patterns across different projects, making it more efficient so you don´t have to rebuild every time. The key features are Process, Transformation, Mapping, Call, Routers, Persistence, Security, and Miscellaneous. Be sure to read the full description of each Pallet and make your own life easier when using the system!

Read the blog post here

Community News

New Progression Badges for Discussion!

Been an active member and speaking your mind also comes with rewards. Now our platform will give badges specifically for members who kick conversations off by starting discussions. The first badge for the first discussion you started, the second for starting three discussions, the third for starting ten, and the fourth for starting twenty. The biggest milestone is the fifith badge, awarded for starting fifty discussions! These five badges set will be awarded retroactively, which means that if you have already initiated discussions in the community, you will be notified. This is our way to recognize the members who take the time to bring positive contributions, educating other members, and connecting! Make sure to read here more details about it.

Preserving the integrity of the community content

We all know how Generative AI can accelerate learning, content creation, and sometimes be very useful. But our SAP Community team believes that it is only worth it when it is used thoughtfully. It is non-negotiable to us, the preservation of trust and accuracy. When someone copies and paste AI-generated answers without verification, the risk of spreading misinformation increases and we lose the essence behind the discussions on SAP Community.  It is highly recommended that if you need to use GenAI tools to draft, plan, and refine your content, the final text still reflects your personal expertise. Now “GenAI Assisted Content” label can be also found and added. SAP´s Anne Petteroe explained all the details on her latest blog post here, and the examples of unacceptable usage. The complete generative AI guidelines for the SAP Community can be found in our Welcome Corner group. 

Have you shared about you on SAP Community Hobbies Series?

Last month, we shared the launch of the SAP Community Hobbies Series, which is a way of sharing the things you love to do and connecting with other members that maybe share the same interests. For this edition, we would like to shoutout our SAP Champion Sebastian Marchesini, that recently posted about his journey with running. This lifelong hobby, for Sebastian it became more than just a sport, but most importantly turned into an enjoyable moment, stress escapism and confidence booster for new challenges. Read here all about his lessons learned with running and join the series, because we would love to know more about what makes you happier!

Events

Devtoberfest 2-week Recap and Petoberfest!

Our SAP community has been showing up and bringing their best in the last two weeks of the Devtoberfest 2025, and first we would like to thank you for interacting and bringing such good energy to the sessions. Starting with ABAP and finishing with CAP, in case you missed or would like to give a second look on any speaker's presentations, here is the list for all last week agenda. Last but not least, the Fun Activities have been such a nice way to challenge everyone and earn points! And the biggest highlight goes for the Petoberfest, with the cutest images of our members' lovely pets (plus the AI generated dogs wearing SAP outfits!). You are definitely not going to regret taking a look at this adorable pictures here.  Let´s not forget that for every activity is possible to earn points for the Grand Prize, the validation tutorials can be found in our Tutorial Navigator. 

Day in the life of a Developer at SAP TechEd

What an amazing way to kick off the SAP TechEd! And in case you are feeling that good anxiety for your days in Berlin, there are many ways to prepare yourself ahead. SAP´s Richard Kuba shared his “Day in the life of a Developer” with his three days agenda including the sessions he is planning to attend. Richard also made sure to include his thoughts on why he thinks participating in SAP TechEd can be super valuable for real-world projects. We are sure that you will feel very inspired as well, so don’t miss it: SAP TechEd Berlin and Virtual happens from November 4 – 6.  

SAP will co-host the next InnerSourceSummit!

The InnerSource Summit 2025 is happening on November 13, bringing nearly 24 hours of global content on hybrid format, from Yokohama, Berlin, and New York. Hosted by SAP, Mitsubishi Electric and IBM, this year’s summit marks the 10th anniversary of the InnerSource Commons Foundation. SAP´s Guilherme Dellagustin, shared on his latest blog post on Berlin Location Group, more details about SAP participation on the event, the full agenda and how to register. If you are available, we encourage you to check it out and bring with you another SAP community member from your area to connect, learn and grow!

entry.title: Triggering Group Reporting Jobs via OData Service
entry.content:
In this post, we’ll look at how to trigger SAP Group Reporting jobs using the OData service BC_EXT_APPJOB_MANAGEMENT.

This API enables you to execute jobs based on templates defined in the Fiori app Application Job Templates. Normally, such jobs can be scheduled directly from the Fiori app Schedule Jobs for Consolidation Tasks (F5572). However, many customers are exploring ways to integrate these job executions with an external scheduler, which is the main focus of this blog.

For a list of supported job templates, refer to the SAP Help Portal:
👉Supported Templates – Schedule Jobs for Consolidation Tasks

The approach described here applies to both S/4HANA Cloud (Public) and Private/On-Premise systems, though the configuration steps may vary slightly between the two environments.

Before diving into the details, it’s worth mentioning that Private and On-Premise customers can also use the XBP (External Background Processing) interface to trigger jobs externally.
XBP is an RFC-based interface that allows external job schedulers to interact with SAP background jobs, such as defining, starting, or monitoring them.

The following sections focus on the OData-based approach, which provides a REST alternative suitable for broader deployment scenarios.

1. Public Cloud Setup
For public cloud, use one of the predefined communication scenarios:

  • SAP_COM_0064 – Application Job Management Integration
  • SAP_COM_0326 – Application Job Scheduling

Configuration step:

  1. Create a Communication System and Communication Arrangement for the chosen scenario.
  2. Follow SAP Note 3119486 to add required fields.

2. Private/On-Premise Setup
For Private Edition or On-Premise systems:

  • Activate the service BC_EXT_APPJOB_MANAGEMENT in transaction /IWFND/MAINT_SERVICE.
  • Test using SAP Gateway Client to make sure it works as expected.
  • Register the external scheduler using the program from SAP Note 3527503 to avoid “scheduler not registered” errors.

3. Triggering the Job
Once the service is activated successfully, it can be tested in Bruno or Postman or integrated into a scheduler’s REST job type. Below is an example done in Bruno for the balance carryforward task:

/sap/opu/odata/SAP/BC_EXT_APPJOB_MANAGEMENT;v=0002/JobSchedule?
JobTemplateName='SAP_FIN_CS_BAL_CARRYFORWARD'&
JobText='Job_Balance_forward'&
JobUser='Jobscheduler'&
JobParameterValues='{{parameters}}'

 Example parameter payload:

const params = {
  VALUES: [
    { NAME: "PA_CONGR", T_VALUE: [{ SIGN: "I", OPTION: "EQ", LOW: "GX1" }] },
    { NAME: "PA_ITCLG", T_VALUE: [{ SIGN: "I", OPTION: "EQ", LOW: "Y1" }] },
    { NAME: "PA_PRVYR", T_VALUE: [{ SIGN: "I", OPTION: "EQ", LOW: "2021" }] },
    { NAME: "PA_RVERS", T_VALUE: [{ SIGN: "I", OPTION: "EQ", LOW: "X01" }] }
  ]
};
bru.setVar("parameters", JSON.stringify(params));

 Once the job is triggered successfully, the response of the request will include job name and job count information:

4. Monitoring

  • Public Cloud: Check job status via the Application Job app or in Data Monitor to check the last run log.

  • Private/On-Premise: Review results in Data Monitor or use transaction SM37 under the scheduler user.

Once the job is executed successfully, the corresponding task (for example, Balance Carryforward) appears as locked in the Data Monitor.



5. Key SAP Notes:

3119486New fields in communication arrangements of type SAP_COM_0064 and SAP_COM_0326
3383044Using the BC_EXT_APPJOB_MANAGEMENT API
3527503BC_EXT_APPJOB_MANAGEMENT in On-Premise

Summary:
Deployment Integration Key Point

Public CloudODataUse SAP_COM_0064 or SAP_COM_0326
Private/On-PremiseOData or XBPManually add service and register scheduler if needed

entry.title: Unlocking the Next Chapter of Seamless Planning in SAP Business Data Cloud with Live Versions
entry.content:
Introduction

Seamless planning is generally available since Q1 2025. Since then, plan data resides directly in SAP Datasphere and with that, in the core of SAP Business Data Cloud. We are now thrilled to announce the release of live versions with QRC4 2025 (fast track wave 20.2025) that bring fact data into planning models without replication! Learn how this works, why it brings many planning use cases to a new level and how it benefits from the data product architecture of BDC. 

I also want to highlight more features that we are introducing in this context:

  • Detection of mismatches between fact and master data (postings on dimension members that are not part of your dimension tables)
  • Planning on live versions from other sources (e.g., Google BigQuery; not applicable for seamless planning and to be covered in a separate blogpost)

Watch out for more blogposts to come in the next weeks!

Use cases & benefits

You cannot plan in a data vacuum. Plans rely on reference data and input. That can be actual data, other plan data, external influencer data etc.  Until now, you were required to physically bring this data into your planning models using import jobs, uploads or data actions. Hence, live versions represent an advanced paradigm to data management and offer benefits in core planning scenarios for different personas. 

Accurate forecasts & plans: Live versions pull actuals, and external drivers directly from SAP Datasphere into your planning models - without replication. This removes latency and reconciliation work, so forecasts are built on the latest, governed facts from a single source of truth. Rolling forecasts and variance analysis become immediate and more reliable, reducing forecast bias and improving plan quality. Live versions can even feed SAP Analytics Cloud predictive scenarios with live data!

Extended Planning and Analysis: Cross-functional teams (finance, supply chain, sales, HR) consume the same governed facts directly from SAP Datasphere. Plans, assumptions and driver changes propagate instantly across domains, enabling end-to-end scenarios, consistent KPIs, and accelerating aligned decisions.

Operating a planning solution: No more nightly imports, manual uploads, or complex data actions to keep models current. Live versions reduce data movement & data footprint, simplify model building & operations, and lower TCO. Furthermore, the graphical modeling interface in SAP Datasphere lets you define joins, mappings, transformations etc. to bring data into the exact shape that you need for your planning model. 

SAP Business Data Cloud's data product architecture augments this opportunity.

  • Use SAP-managed data products and base planning models directly on curated data from SAP applications.
  • Use customer-managed data products from SAP BW PCE to support hybrid planning architectures while transitioning from BPC to planning in BDC. 
  • Integrate results from SAP Databricks via SAP Datasphere

How does it work?

Add data to an existing model

  • In your model details, you will find a new entry in the ‘Data’ section which is called ‘External Live Version Data Sources’
  • Here, ‘Connect External Data Source’
  • Choose an existing target version for the data source or create a blank version
  • Choose your fact view from your model’s SAP Datasphere space
  • Map the data source columns to your model’s columns
    • Not all source columns need to be mapped
    • Not all target columns need to be mapped
      • Measures can be NULL
      • Dimensions can receive a default member
    • Certain data type differences can be handled
  • If we detect a mismatch between the live version and your master data, we will notify you and you can add missing dimension members directly (not shown in the video)
  • You’re done! You can add more sources to the model, if you want

Adding a live version to a model

Build a model from an SAP Datasphere view

  • Create a new model
  • ‘Start with data’
  • Select SAP Datasphere as data storage location (=use seamless planning)
  • Select a space. The view you want to use as basis for the planning model must be in the same space or shared with the space
  • Select SAP Datasphere as datasource
  • Select your view
  • You now already see the live connection to the source view data
  • Create dimension tables as needed
  • Save the model
  • You’re done!

A usage example

In the following example, we add headcount (full-time equivalent / FTE) data to the previously created sales planning model because we want to add a calculation of revenue generated per sales employee.

  • We have an FTE planning model which is deployed to our SAP Datasphere space. Note that the fact table is exposed in the data builder.
  • We create a view on the fact table with a filter on sales employees in SAP Datasphere
  • We add the view to our sales planning model, do the mappings and add a calculation
  • In the story, we see the live data from the FTE planning model and the calculation result
  • When we change data in the FTE planning and publish it, the calculation in the sales model is refreshed in real-time

FAQ

Where can I use this feature?

This feature is available for SAP Analytics Cloud models that use SAP Datasphere as data storage location (=seamless planning models).

Can I use any fact table/view from SAP Datasphere?

You can use fact views that are exposed for consumption. They must be available in the space that your model is deployed to. They can be shared with the space as well.

Can I also add data from other planning models?

You can add data from other seamless planning models if they are deployed and exposed in the same space or if the exposed data has been shared from another space. You need to create a view on top of the tables which is exposed for consumption.

What can I do with live versions? (And what can I not do?)

You can display the live version data in the model data foundation and in tables, charts, etc. in stories.

You can reference the live version data in model and story calculations as well as data actions (incl. advanced formulas).

You cannot write back into the referenced views (or rather their underlying tables). You can copy the live version data into planning versions via copy/paste in the table, data actions and version management.

How do I see if data is live or not?

In models, a live version is highlighted in the data preview. In the version dimension, you see the data source per version.  

In tables, live version data is locked for data entry and formatted accordingly. Reasons for unplannable data give accurate information.

Is SAP Datasphere Data Access Control considered?

Yes, it is.

Do planners need to have certain roles in SAP Datasphere?

Only if a user has a consumer role for the underlying space, he will be able to see live version data. Otherwise, he can use the planning model but will not see live version data.

Data access control applies as well.

What about live access to master data?

Live access to master data is future enhancement with high priority.

Conclusion

Live versions bring seamless planning to the next level and unlock a lot of value for planning in SAP Business Data Cloud. I am delighted to announce the general availability in Q4 2025.

entry.title: UI5 - TypeScript: Wrapping OData Calls with Promise (Solving Problems… Barely 😅)
entry.content:
Apologies in advance, as I am not a good writer.

Premise: - In my recent project, the client had some very strict coding practices

  1. No callbacks — use Promises only
  2. Follow KISS and DRY principles
  3. Keep code modular
  4. Don’t mix business logic with UI logic

My first thought?

What do you mean use promises? 
The OData V2 model is callback-based. 
Avoid business logic ?? 😲
 No more 2500 lines of controller code, What am I supposed to do with all this free space?
It was very scary (Obvious Skill issue 😁)..
The Plan:- 


So, as I really can't write an Article, I'll try to show some code examples which can be helpful to "MODERNIZE" promise-based OData calls

Step 1: - Create a promise-based wrapper utility
File: - assertNever.ts

export default function assertNever(value: never): never {
    throw new Error(`Unhandled/Unsupported case: ${String(value)}`);
};

File: - promiseOdata.ts 

/* eslint-disable linebreak-style */
import Deferred from "sap/base/util/Deferred";
import ODataModel from "sap/ui/model/odata/v2/ODataModel";
import assertNever from "./assertNever";

//Types
type RemoveCallbacks<T> = Omit<Exclude<T, undefined>, "success" | "error">;
export type ReadParam = RemoveCallbacks<Parameters<typeof ODataModel.prototype.read>[1]>;
export type RemoveParam = RemoveCallbacks<Parameters<typeof ODataModel.prototype.remove>[1]>;
export type CreateParam = RemoveCallbacks<Parameters<typeof ODataModel.prototype.create>[2]>;
export type UpdateParam = RemoveCallbacks<Parameters<typeof ODataModel.prototype.update>[2]>;
export type ODataParams = ReadParam | RemoveParam | CreateParam | UpdateParam | undefined;
type ODataMethodReturn = { abort: () => void };
type PromiseODataReturn<T> = { promise: Promise<T>, abort?: ODataMethodReturn["abort"] };

type ODataParamByAction =
    { action: "read", options?: ReadParam }
    | { action: "remove", options?: RemoveParam }
    | { action: "create", payload: object, options?: CreateParam }
    | { action: "update", payload: object, options?: UpdateParam };


export default function promiseOdata<T>(
    model: ODataModel,
    path: string,
    param: ODataParamByAction
): PromiseODataReturn<T> {
    const { promise, resolve, reject } = new Deferred<T>();
    const addResolvers = (options?: ODataParams) => {
        return { ...options, success: resolve, error: reject };
    };

    let abort = () => { };
    switch (param.action) {
        case "read":
            abort = (model.read(path, addResolvers(param.options)) as ODataMethodReturn).abort;
            break;
        case "remove":
            abort = (model.remove(path, addResolvers(param.options)) as ODataMethodReturn).abort;
            break;
        case "create":
            abort = (model.create(path, param.payload, addResolvers(param.options)) as ODataMethodReturn).abort;
            break;
        case "update":
            abort = (model.update(path, param.payload, addResolvers(param.options)) as ODataMethodReturn).abort;
            break;
        default:
        // Exhaustiveness check
        assertNever(param);
    }

    return { promise, abort };
}

Step 2: - Create a central Class for CRUD calls (Separation of concerns)
File: - DataManager.ts

import BaseObject from "sap/ui/base/Object";
import Filter from "sap/ui/model/Filter";
import ODataModel from "sap/ui/model/odata/v2/ODataModel";
import promiseOdata from "tsapp/utils/promiseOdata";

/**
 *  tsapp.helper
 */
export default class DataManager extends BaseObject {
    private readonly _model: ODataModel;

    constructor(model: ODataModel) {
        super();
        this._model = model;
    }

    metadataLoaded(){
        return this._model.metadataLoaded()
    }

    getCategories(filter?: Filter[]) {
        // Intentionally passing generic T as "any", don't feel like creating Type defs for the demo 😅
        return promiseOdata<any>(this._model, "/Categories", { action: "read", options: { filters: filter } });
    }

    getCategory(CategoryID: number | string) {
        const path = this._model.createKey("/Categories", { CategoryID });
        return promiseOdata(this._model, path, {
            action: "read",
            options: {
                urlParameters: {
                    $expand: "products"
                }
            }
        })
    }

    //.. other methods for different calls

}

Step 3: - Use in Controller,  Component (Snippet from controller)

import DataManager from "tsapp/helper/DataManager";
import BaseController from "./BaseController";
import Component from "tsapp/Component";
import ODataModel from "sap/ui/model/odata/v2/ODataModel";

/**
 *  tsapp.controller
 */
export default class CategoryDetail extends BaseController{
    protected _dataManager: DataManager

    onInit(): void  {
        const component = this.getOwnerComponent() as Component
        this._dataManager = new DataManager(component.getModel() as ODataModel);
    }

    async loadCategory(id: number | string){
       await this._dataManager?.metadataLoaded(); // Wait until metadata is loaded
       const {promise, abort /*Can be used to abort pending request */} = await this._dataManager.getCategory(id);
       //not wrapping in try/cath for simple demo 🤞
       const data = await promise;
       console.log(data);
    }
}
